segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 52
segments.en: Linked Discourses 52

segments.pli: 1. Rahogatavagga
segments.en: 1. In Private

segments.pli: 8. Salaḷāgārasutta
segments.en: 8. The Frankincense-Tree Hut

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho sāvatthiyaṃ viharati salaḷāgāre.
segments.en: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the frankincense-tree hut.

segments.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā anuruddho bhikkhū āmantesi … pe … etadavoca:
segments.en: There Venerable Anuruddha addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: “seyyathāpi, āvuso, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā.
segments.en: “Reverends, suppose that, although the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east,

segments.pli: Atha mahājanakāyo āgaccheyya kudālapiṭakaṃ ādāya:
segments.en: a large crowd were to come along with a spade and basket, saying:

segments.pli: ‘mayaṃ imaṃ gaṅgānadiṃ pacchāninnaṃ karissāma pacchāpoṇaṃ pacchāpabbhāran’ti.
segments.en: ‘We’ll make this Ganges river slant, slope, and incline to the west!’

segments.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññathāvuso, api nu so mahājanakāyo gaṅgānadiṃ pacchāninnaṃ kareyya pacchāpoṇaṃ pacchāpabbhāran”ti?
segments.en: What do you think, reverends? Would they succeed?”

segments.pli: “No hetaṃ, āvuso”.
segments.en: “No, reverend.

segments.pli: “Taṃ kissa hetu”?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: “Gaṅgā, āvuso, nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā.
segments.en: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

segments.pli: Sā na sukarā pacchāninnaṃ kātuṃ pacchāpoṇaṃ pacchāpabbhāraṃ.
segments.en: It’s not easy to make it slant, slope, and incline to the west.

segments.pli: Yāvadeva ca pana so mahājanakāyo kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
segments.en: That large crowd will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

segments.pli: “Evameva kho, āvuso, bhikkhuṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāventaṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkarontaṃ rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā bhogehi abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavāreyyuṃ:
segments.en: “In the same way, while a mendicant develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, if rulers or their ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or family should invite them to accept wealth, saying:

segments.pli: ‘ehambho purisa, kiṃ te ime kāsāvā anudahanti?
segments.en: ‘Please, mister, why let these ocher robes torment you?

segments.pli: Kiṃ muṇḍo kapālamanusañcarasi?
segments.en: Why follow the practice of shaving your head and carrying an alms bowl?

segments.pli: Ehi hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu puññāni ca karohī’ti.
segments.en: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!’

segments.pli: So vata, āvuso, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
segments.en: It’s simply impossible for a mendicant who is developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation to reject the training and return to a lesser life.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, cittaṃ dīgharattaṃ vivekaninnaṃ vivekapoṇaṃ vivekapabbhāraṃ taṃ vata hīnāyāvattissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
segments.en: Because for a long time that mendicant’s mind has slanted, sloped, and inclined to seclusion. So it’s impossible for them to return to a lesser life.

segments.pli: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveti, cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkarotīti?
segments.en: And how does a mendicant develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

segments.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati … pe …
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body …

segments.pli: vedanāsu … pe …
segments.en: feelings …

segments.pli: citte … pe …
segments.en: mind …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveti, cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkarotī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

segments.pli: Aṭṭhamaṃ.

sections.title: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī…

suttaplex.blurb: Even if kings beg them to disrobe, a mendicant who has developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation is unmoved. Their mind flows to Nibbāna like the Ganges to the sea.
